body: The git repo is empty, or no/incorrect default branch?

I am experiencing the same issue, also on Gitea 1.23.5 from upstream binary on Debian 12. This is against repository https://git.nixmagic.com/vim/urldeconstruct . Currently set private, was looking for docs on how to set this thing public as I stumbled upon this issue.
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/42650cc9-47b0-4db5-ab9e-cc3c01778ea2)

FWIW, this repository was created from scratch, with a custom root commit. The branch chosen as default, was "dev". I seek not to engage in what branch "should" be default. It was created and pushed in the following workflow:

```
mkdir -p toloveru/repo
cd toloveru/repo
git init
git branch -m dev
[edit files]
git add .
git remote add gitea https://git.nixmagic.com/vim/urldeconstruct
git push --set-upstream gitea dev
git commit -m "Add screenshot of urldeconstruct" 
git push
```

Might've been slightly off, going from command history here. If you're as familiar with Git as I am, I'm sure you know what to add and/or reshuffle.

> FWIW, this repository was created from scratch, with a custom root commit. The branch chosen as default, was "dev". I seek not to engage in what branch "should" be default. It was created and pushed in the following workflow:

I think it is the problem. The record in database thinks that "main" is the default branch.

Could you try to change the default branch from repo settings?

issue.title: Do not show 500 error when default branch doesn't exist

repository.name: gitea
repository.description: Git with a cup of tea! Painless self-hosted all-in-one software development service, including Git hosting, code review, team collaboration, package registry and CI/CD

body: ->  Do not show 500 error when default branch doesn't exist #34096

> > FWIW, this repository was created from scratch, with a custom root commit. The branch chosen as default, was "dev". I seek not to engage in what branch "should" be default. It was created and pushed in the following workflow:
> 
> I think it is the problem. The record in database thinks that "main" is the default branch.
> 
> Could you try to change the default branch from repo settings?

Sure! Updating the default branch seems to have fixed the 500 on the activity tab. Default was "main", existing branch is "dev", and local default in Git is "master". I suppose it raises a question of choice and consistency. Oh well. Hopefully #34096 managed to address it successfully for when it's inconsistent. Thanks for having done that!

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/e5132eb2-395d-4580-991c-4dde6e8d124e)
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/4ee14d8b-3667-4b21-84ce-684530134731)
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/d378b2ac-0893-45fe-9f48-5e9eceeea3f1)

> I suppose it raises a question of choice and consistency.

Gitea will try to use "main" or "master" as the default branch if any exists, but it doesn't guess others.

So when you push a repo with only a "dev" branch, at the moment, Gitea won't use it as default branch. It was designed that many pages should work when default branch is missing ðŸ˜„

Fair enough, it's hard to justify endless additions for possible defaults when there's any code that depends on one or maybe two possible values (not to mention that most repositories are now indeed master or main).

Perhaps a better question to ask than "what should this value be" would be to ask if we can switch from one to an infinite number of possible values, and where we grab that value from.

When I log into the server that runs my Gitea instance and run a couple of Git commands against some of my repositories (being careful not to write new data!), I found that branches can be listed, but that only urldeconstruct has a selected branch. The repository itube meanwhile (which has not had this web UI change made yet), does not have a selected branch.

I wonder if there are any Git commands that can reliably return this branch name, and how that would be affected if multiple branches (of which none are master/main) are defined. ~~Not to mention that not all back-ends are filesystem per se (notably database services)...~~
It would appear that on my SQLite back-end, this only applies to `data/gitea.db`. Not sure how that applies to other back-ends, but would it be reasonable to assume repository data to be present as filesystem structures on all of them?

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/557dc45e-2825-4761-8246-292db177f003)

As far as suitable Git commands go, `git checkout --guess` struck me as interesting. However, it seems to be unable to guess the correct branch when none are already selected. Meanwhile in terms of running potentially harmful commands against the on-server repository, I decided to use rsync to grab a local copy of what's on server. While inconclusive, I'll include my findings for reference. The `git branch -l` command may be suitable-ish, but I don't like the * on selected branch, and leading space(s) regardless. And it may have multiple branches, only separated by newlines... What are we supposed to do with those?

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/adcb9b92-5b59-4dde-b335-38e022309140)

Come to think of it, isn't there already code in Gitea that determines a list of possible branches? That would be what I looked at in the listing for selecting a suitable default branch. That code probably "knew" that neither main nor master are in the default branches, on account of only listing dev. In single branch scenarios, that being implied default would be a reasonable assumption to make. Meanwhile in multiple branch scenarios, I guess it would be worth asking the user before setting the selected default branch in Git? Especially considering that such a use case would be even more niche than creating repositories from scratch with custom branch names already is...

In Gitea, "SetDefaultBranch" just does `git symbolic-ref HEAD refs/heads/master`:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3559649f-654a-4a09-875b-e26ffefa858b)

That's it! `refs/heads` contains the branches of that repository, as files in a directory! We only need to list those, to determine what branches are in a given repository. We can either diverge into "nonstandard" logic when master/main are not found, or determine what code currently uses that as an anchor and make all of it run against a dynamic branch instead. Heck, even a function's abstraction of master => actual_name would not necessarily be off the table. If that aids in keeping current logic stable, by all means use it! Just don't forget to make the long-term goalpost be direct addressing is all.
